column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=Leaf Odours versus Floral Odours
#Text=
#Text=When we compare leaf odours with flower odours we
#Text=find a considerable difference between them.
#Text=Thus in
#Text=the case of the orange there is a difference between the
#Text=essential oils of the flowers and of the leaves, and of that
#Text=of the rind of the fruit, which afford three different
#Text=kinds of perfume.
#Text=Then floral odours are generally positive, being exhaled
#Text=by most flowers spontaneously as it were, so that you
#Text=must inhale floral odours whether you like them or not.
#Text=Leaf odours, on the other hand, are latent or negative,
#Text=and are rarely to be detected except after the leaves have
#Text=been touched, pressed, or bruised.
#Text=Both leaf and flower
#Text=perfume depends on the same essential oil being in
#Text=different states or conditions.
#Text=Floral odours again are emitted only at particular
#Text=times, that is to say, just when the androecia] whorl
#Text=attains maturity, and the flowers are quite fresh ; and
#Text=even then, in the case of many Orchids and other flowers,
#Text=their scent is intermittent, and only to be perceived at
#Text=different times of the day or night — this time, as we
#Text=suppose, having some connection with the diurnal or
#Text=nocturnal visits of the insects that act as marriage priests
#Text=in their native wilds.
#Text=But, on the other hand, leaf odours
#Text=are persistent —  ready if sought" seems to be their
#Text=motto — and not only are scented leaves fragrant when
#Text=green and fresh, but often retain their perfume long after
#Text=they are yellow or brown and sere.
